answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Erin,
Since Florida is a special case, there are many documents discussing how local governments should approach social media while keeping in line with the Public Records Act. They should prove useful to you as they also discuss the process of public record maintenance on social media sites.  
The Institute for Local Government provides two documents: Florida Attorney General Opinion and Coral Springs City Attorney Analysis that have helped to inform the social media polices of many jurisdictions in the state. 
http://www.ca-ilg.org/socialmediaFloridaLaw
An article from the Florida Bar journal that discusses Florida’s public records laws, retention of records from social media websites, common practices in capturing records and challenges. It also explains a new offsite  tool known as GovLive Vault that facilitates the retention of public records by taking digital images from sites like Facebook, twitter and YouTube. 
http://www.floridabar.org/DIVCOM/JN/JNJournal01.nsf/d59e2cf27607c0cf85256ad1005ba53f/5fa8e4007731316a85257881006b503d!OpenDocument 
The Coral Springs media center website states that all information posted on the City’s Facebook page is maintained for a minimum of 30 days in accordance with the retention schedule of the state. 
http://www.coralsprings.org/mediacenter/facebook.cfm?CFID=3581654&CFTOKEN=97291512&jsessionid=f0305c38a010ee44a26d4660712015172165 
A document on the Knowledge Network called the City of Boyton Beach, Administrative Policy for using social networking sites, outlines the responsibilities of employees as all information is subject to public records.  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301893/City_of_Boynton_Beach_Florida_Administrative_Policy_Manual
And finally an article, Social Media: The good, the Bad and the Ugly for Municipalities, on the Knowledge Network that is a useful read for municipal attorneys who are involved in the process of creating social media policies. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302444/Social_Media_The_Good_the_Bad_and_the_Ugly_for_Municipalities
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja Varma 
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Erin Bryce
text:
The City of North Port, Florida is working on a social media policy. Specifically, I'd like to know how Florida cities and counties are capturing public records when it comes to social media tools like Facebook and Twitter.
I've heard that you can take "print screen" screen shots of your web page and save the activity that way. Is there a more effective way to capture the information?
Please let me know by sending me an e-mail at ebryce@cityofnorthport.com. Thank you for your help.
title: Social Media and Public Records Laws in Florida
